Improving Financial Inclusion in Asia and the Pacific 
(Cofinanced by the Financial Sector Development Partnership 
Fund)

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Financial  inclusion  is  broadly  recognized  as  a  key  to  development,  because  of  its 
positive effects on economic growth and poverty reduction.1 Financial inclusion evolved from the 
modern microfinance movement and aims to empower poor individuals, low-income households, 
and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through affordable access to and adequate 
usage of a broad range of regulated financial products and services, including credit, deposit, 
insurance, remittance, and payment.  
 
2.  Financial inclusion has gained tremendous political momentum since it was incorporated 
in the Group of Twenty (G20) development agenda at the Pittsburgh Summit in September 2009. 
In 2010, the G20 financial inclusion initiative was marked by two major milestones: adoption of 
the nine principles for innovative financial inclusion at the Toronto Summit,2 and the launch of 
the Global Partnership for Financial Inclusion (GPFI) following the Seoul Summit.3 In addition to 
the global forum under the G20, financial inclusion is also being pursued by the Asia-Pacific 
Economic Cooperation forum, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and the Pacific 
Islands Financial Inclusion Working Group.  
 
3.  ADB’s Financial Sector Operational Plan, adopted in 2011 to guide implementation of 
the financial sector agendas under ADB’s Strategy 2020, identified financial inclusion as one of 
the two priority areas for ADB operations in the financial sector.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  ADB has been very active in the area of financial inclusion. Under the ADB project 
classification system, at least two of the financial sector’s nine subsectors—microfinance, and 
SME finance and leasing—deal with financial inclusion issues.5 As of 7 September 2012, ADB 
had approved 121 projects amounting to $2.59 billion for microfinance and 92 projects worth 
$1.5 billion for SME finance and leasing, including public sector loans, technical assistance (TA), 
grants, and nonsovereign operations. In light of the keen interest of ADB’s developing member 
countries (DMCs) in financial inclusion initiatives at global and regional forums and in light of the 
Financial Sector Operational Plan, ADB should strengthen its assistance to DMCs and play a 
leading role in steering and advancing financial inclusion in Asia and the Pacific. To this end, it 
is important to address several issues.

5  The nine subsectors are (i) banking systems, (ii) money and capital markets, (iii) investment funds, (iv) housing 
finance, (v) microfinance, (vi) SME finance and leasing, (vii) trade finance, (viii) insurance and contractual savings, 
and (ix) finance sector development. ADB projects classified under other sectors may also involve access to finance 
components.

2 
 
 
5.  Peer learning and knowledge sharing. A key approach adopted by the G20 financial 
inclusion action plan was peer learning and knowledge sharing among stakeholders, particularly 
in developing countries. This approach has recently been highlighted again and encouraged by 
G20  leaders  as  a  way  to  effectively  implement  the  G20  principles  for  innovative  financial 
inclusion.6 ADB’s past operations on financial inclusion produced many project documents, 
consultants’ reports, and performance reviews from which experience and lessons could be 
derived  on  the  design  and  implementation  of  financial  inclusion  strategies,  programs,  and 
projects in different contexts and in the face of various constraints. However, a user-friendly and 
searchable ―knowledge base‖ is currently not available for DMCs and other stakeholders to 
conveniently access this information. 
 
6.  Financial inclusion in Asia and the Pacific. Financial inclusion is a relatively new, 
evolving initiative that came to the attention of high-level policy dialogues primarily through 
global forums, and in particular the G20. These have set forth very broad principles, whose 
implementation requires a good understanding of the special characteristics and context in each 
region and country. Asia and the Pacific is a very disparate region, economically and socially, 
with specific features and particular challenges for financial inclusion, such as (i) government-
dominant  models,  with  extensive  networks  of  postal  banks  in  most  countries;  (ii)  savings 
cultures; (iii) active informal markets for lending, insurance, and remittance; and (iv) migration of 
labor within countries and abroad. In-depth analysis and understanding of issues that are of 
pertinent interest and relevance for Asia and the Pacific would be a prerequisite for effective, 
context-specific implementation of the G20 principles for innovative financial inclusion.  
 
7.  Financial  consumer  protection  and  financial  literacy.  The  2007–2009  global 
economic  crisis  and  incidents  in  local  microfinance  markets  have  underscored  the  critical 
importance  of  financial  consumer  protection  and  financial  literacy  as  elements  of  financial 
inclusion. High-level principles for financial consumer protection were endorsed by the G20 in 
2011, while national strategies for financial education were endorsed in 2012. At the Los Cabos 
Summit in June 2012, G20 leaders further emphasized this subject by supporting the creation of 
a fourth GPFI subgroup that will focus on consumer protection and financial literacy. ADB’s 
Independent Evaluation Department has addressed these issues and indicated in its special 
evaluation study on ADB’s Microfinance Development Strategy that ADB should place greater 
focus on clients, in particular on consumer protection and financial literacy.7 
 
8.  The foregoing (paras. 5–7) does not cover all the issues raised by financial inclusion in 
Asia and the Pacific. However, these three interconnected areas reflect the most recent trends 
in financial inclusion, emphasize the relevance of the efforts for the region and DMCs’ needs, 
and attempt to make optimum use of ADB’s experience in taking a leading role in promoting 
financial inclusion regionally. Addressing these issues would be particularly helpful to ensure the 
relevance,  effectiveness,  and  overall  quality  of  financial  inclusion  projects  that  ADB  is 
processing or planning with DMCs. Furthermore, the TA will also better prepare DMCs to take 
advantage of new opportunities offered by financial inclusion in Asia and the Pacific, and gain 
more confidence in embracing new and scaled up financial inclusion projects in their country 
programming process with ADB.  
                                                
6  G20 Leaders Declaration. Los Cabos Summit in June 2012. http://www.g20mexico.org/ 
7  Independent Evaluation Department. 2012. Special Evaluation Study: Microfinance Development Strategy 2000—
Sector  Performance  and  Client  Welfare.  Manila:  ADB.  http://www.adb.org/documents/adbs-microfinance-

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be improved financial inclusion in Asia and the Pacific. The 
outcome will be better understanding and enhanced capacity of ADB’s DMCs in promoting 
financial inclusion.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will provide support at the regional level to DMCs through three outputs: (i) a 
knowledge platform for financial inclusion, (ii) a study on selected issues related to financial 
inclusion,  and  (iii)  diagnosis  and  experience  sharing  on financial  consumer  protection  and 
financial literacy. 
 
11.  Output 1. The knowledge platform, to be hosted on the ADB website, will focus on 
providing a comprehensive and user-friendly source of information on ADB’s experience and 
lessons from previous operations related to financial inclusion. To this end, an overall plan will 
be developed to (i) structure and classify the contents of the knowledge platform, (ii) set up key 
subjects or themes to facilitate online research by users, and (iii) establish a mechanism for the 
maintenance  and  updating  of  the  knowledge  platform.  The  platform  will  be  created  in 
consultation with the Office of Information Systems and Technology (OIST) to ensure linkages 
with its work on data integration and knowledge platforms in collaboration with the Economics 
and Research Department (ERD) and the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI). 
 
12.  ADB project documents, consultants’ reports, and performance review reports related to 
financial inclusion will be collected, summarized or annotated, and posted online under a set of 
yet-to-be-determined  themes.8 This  will  be  undertaken  in  coordination  with  the  knowledge 
sharing and services center of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD), 
which is designing an ADB-wide framework to extract and share embedded knowledge from 
ADB operations.  
 
13.  The same thematic index will also be used as the basis for posting and regular online 
updating of information on the latest trends and literature on financial inclusion. In addition, a 
quarterly e-newsletter on financial inclusion will be issued as a platform for ADB staff and 
consultants and other practitioners to share insights, experience, and summary publications on 
financial inclusion. At the completion of the TA, the knowledge platform will be maintained, with 
the contents to be adjusted if necessary based on feedback from DMCs and other users. 
Funding to sustain the knowledge platform will be provided from a follow-up TA or through 
reassignment of staff resources within OREI.  
 
14.  Output 2. The study on selected issues related to financial inclusion will help decision 
makers and other stakeholders in DMCs in considering key issues and concepts relating to 
financial inclusion that are of particular relevance for Asia and the Pacific. Major topics would 
tentatively include (i) partnerships between the public and private sectors to extend financial 
services to the poor and reduce poverty without distorting the market; (ii) the role of state-owned 
financial institutions in financial inclusion, and reforms needed to enable them to fulfill this role; 
(iii) the impact of restrictions on interest rates in microfinance; (iv) the impact of trade financing

4 
 
on access to financing for SMEs; (v) a comparative study of legal concepts and practical 
applications of a ―level playing field‖ for market-oriented financial inclusion; and (vi) constraints, 
applicability,  and  lessons from mobile  technology-based financial  services  in  Asia  and the 
Pacific. This list will be fine-tuned based on surveys that will be conducted with ADB operations 
staff and DMC officials. When relevant and appropriate, the study will analyze the policies, legal 
frameworks, and practical experience of developed countries for comparison and as a reference 
for DMCs. The study will be conducted in coordination as necessary with concerned centers of 
excellence on financial inclusion, such as the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor. Depending 
on the topics and areas covered by the studies, the major findings and recommendations will be 
disseminated  through  pertinent  global  or  regional  workshops  and  conferences  on  financial 
inclusion attended by ADB. Dissemination will primarily be the responsibility of ADB staff, but 
could also be undertaken by the study authors as needed (funding for this is budgeted under the 
TA).  
 
15.  Output  3.  The  diagnosis  and  experience  sharing  regarding  financial  consumer 
protection and financial literacy will target DMCs that have received ADB lending support for 
microfinance and SME finance—a total of 15 countries.9 This component will concentrate on 
(i) financial consumer protection and financial literacy general principles and best practices 
(including  regulatory  and  supervisory  frameworks,  self-regulation  and  responsible  business 
conduct, recourse mechanisms and law enforcement, governance and transparency, usury 
rates and predatory lending, overindebtedness and reckless credit, debt collection practices, 
financial literacy and education, individual insolvency and bankruptcy); (ii) diagnosis of policy 
and  legal  frameworks  and  current  practices  regarding  financial  consumer  protection  and 
financial literacy in participating DMCs; (iii) case studies of success stories and lessons in these 
DMCs; and (iv) recommendations for policy makers on possible options to enhance financial 
consumer protection and improve financial literacy under the overall framework of financial 
inclusion.  
 
16.  Each financial consumer protection and financial literacy diagnosis and case study is 
expected  to  be  country-specific,  addressing  particular  needs  and  constraints  in  individual 
participating DMCs. These will be conducted by each country’s national consultant, under the 
guidance of the international consultant for output 3. The inputs of the national consultants will 
be discussed and supplemented at a consultation workshop at ADB headquarters that will be 
attended by officials from participating DMCs. These inputs as well as the outcome of the 
consultation  workshop  will  be  consolidated  into  the  general  report  on  financial  consumer 
protection and financial literacy in ADB DMCs. 
 
17.  The prospectus and e-link to the knowledge platform that will be created by the TA under 
the ADB website will be provided to leading knowledge centers in financial inclusion industry for 
wider dissemination on their websites.10 All reports and other outputs resulting from the TA will 
be  posted  on  the  knowledge  platform.  The  studies  of  selected  issues  related  to  financial 
inclusion under output 2 and the general report on financial consumer protection and financial 
literacy  under  output  3  will  also  be  disseminated  through  financial  sector  development 
community of practice knowledge events within ADB, as well as through appropriate workshops 
and knowledge events outside ADB. Partnership will be actively sought for translation and 
publication of the studies and report in local languages.  
                                                
9  Invitation to participate in activities under output 3 will be issued to Bangladesh, Cambodia, the People’s Republic 
of  China,  India,  Indonesia, Kazakhstan,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Mongolia,  Pakistan,  Papua  New  Guinea,  the 
Philippines, Tajikistan, Thailand, Uzbekistan, and Viet Nam.  
10 Such as the Alliance for Financial Inclusion, Consultative Group to Assist the Poor, Microfinance Gateway, MIX 
Market, and the Pacific Financial Inclusion Program. Collaboration to efficiently share and make best use of 
knowledge and information hosted on each knowledge center’s website will also be explored.

5 
 
18.  The above activities and outputs will provide improved access to knowledge, experience, 
insights, and lessons on financial inclusion; clarify key issues on financial inclusion in the 
context of Asia and the Pacific; and improve financial consumer protection and financial literacy, 
which will help ADB’s DMCs better understand, enhance their capacity to promote, and improve 
the environment for financial inclusion. Based on DMCs’ needs and in coordination with ADB’s 
operations departments, the TA studies and report could be converted to training materials in 
possible follow-up country or regional-level TA for capacity development of policy makers, 
financial regulators and supervisors, and other practitioners of financial inclusion.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund and administered by ADB;11 and 
(ii) $250,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-IV). The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. No activities will be 
undertaken in a participating country until the requisite no-objection has been or is deemed to 
have been obtained.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will be the executing agency. The TA will be implemented by OREI from January 
2013  to  March  2015. Seven  international  consultants  (17  person-months)  and  18  national 
 
consultants (67 person-months) will help with TA implementation. The assignments will be 
carried out independently, and the TA will engage individual consultants with demonstrated 
expertise in the area and research subject. An ADB staff team from OREI12 will regularly monitor 
and administer the individual contracts, and manage the combined outputs to achieve the TA 
objectives.  
 
21.  The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). TA funds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
22.  ADB will purchase equipment (i.e., computer hardware and software) in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and in coordination with 
the Office of Information Systems and Technology and the Office of Administrative Services, 
where applicable. After TA completion, any equipment that was procured will be disposed of in 
compliance with the project administration instructions on administering grant-financed TA.
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund, and (ii) ADB 
providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis, for Improving 
Financial Inclusion in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.  
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

B.   Terms of Reference 
 
2.     Financial inclusion consultants (international, six assignments, 2 person-months each, 
intermittent). Each consultant will conduct a study of a key financial inclusion issue, as identified 
by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and in particular taking into account feedback from 
surveys with ADB operations staff and developing member country (DMC) officials. The results 
of these studies are expected to help decision makers in DMCs and other stakeholders in 
considering the issues reviewed in each study, and support ADB operations. Each assignment 
will take about 2 person-months, but assignments may be extended to 3 months if warranted. 
The consultants will have a suitable educational background and well-established research 
record on the topics they are assigned; subject to their qualifications and areas of expertise, one 
consultant  may  take  on  more  than  one  assignment.  The  tasks  and  responsibilities  of  the 
consultants will include:    
(i)  conduct literature review and prepare background note on the topic identified by 
ADB; 
(ii)  conduct research using methodologies as agreed with the designated Office of 
Regional Economic Integration (OREI) staff; 
(iii)  present research findings to the designated OREI staff; 
(iv)  draft, revise, and finalize the papers in consultation with the designated OREI 
staff; 
(v)  review and provide comments on other studies under the TA as required by the 
designated OREI staff; and 
(vi)  assist ADB with the publication and dissemination of research outcomes. 
 
3.     Financial  consumer  protection  and  financial  literacy  specialist  (international, 
5 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will have overall responsibility for diagnosis and 
experience sharing on financial consumer protection and financial literacy under the TA. The 
specialist will have a minimum of a master’s degree in law, finance, or economics, and be highly

Appendix 3  11 
knowledgeable  on  financial  consumer  protection  and  financial  education  regulations  and 
practices. The tasks and responsibilities of the specialist will include: 
(i)  prepare  a  detailed  plan  for  diagnosis  and  experience  sharing  on  financial 
consumer protection and financial literacy under the TA, including the outlines for 
general and country reports and a concept for a knowledge and experience 
sharing workshop for participating DMCs; 
(ii)  conduct analytical research and prepare background papers on the rationale for, 
and key principles and evolution of financial consumer protection and financial 
literacy, as well as on other key issues; 
(iii)  provide guidance to participating DMC national consultants on collection of data 
and materials, and writing of inputs for country reports;   
(iv)  serve as a facilitator or resource person at the workshop with participating DMCs 
to  share  experience  on  financial  inclusion  and  seek  feedback  on  the  draft 
comprehensive report;  
(v)  draft the comprehensive report on financial consumer protection and financial 
literacy (including general and country reports); 
(vi)  finalize the report on financial consumer protection and financial literacy, taking 
into account the views and comments of participating DMCs; and 
(vii)  assist with the publication and dissemination of the final report. 
 
4.     Financial inclusion sector analyst (national, 24 person-months). The analyst will be 
headquarters-based  and  will  be  responsible  for  overall  TA  coordination  and  provision  of 
technical  support  for  TA  implementation.  The  analyst  will  have  relevant  educational 
qualifications and work experience, excellent written and verbal communication skills in English, 
and strong capacity for problem solving and achievement of results. The analyst will work 
fulltime over the 2-year period and in cooperation with designated OREI staff in carrying out the 
following tasks: 
(i)  develop an overall plan to structure and classify the contents of the knowledge 
platform, set up key themes to facilitate online research by users, and establish a 
mechanism for the maintenance and updating of the knowledge platform; 
(ii)  collect, summarize, annotate, and present in user-friendly and searchable online 
format ADB project documents, consultants’ reports, and performance review 
reports on financial inclusion; 
(iii)  collect  and  post  online  information  on  the  latest  trends  in  and  literature  on 
financial inclusion; 
(iv)  coordinate the  publication  of,  edit,  and finalize  the quarterly  e-newsletter  on 
financial inclusion to provide a platform for ADB staff, consultants, and other 
practitioners to share their insights, experience, and summary publications on 
financial inclusion; 
(v)  maintain the financial inclusion subsite under the ADB website and portal; and 
(vi)  provide  other  support  in  connection  with  the  implementation  of  the  TA  as 
requested by the designated OREI staff. 
 
5.     Research  analyst  (national,  24  person-months).  The  analyst  will  be  headquarters-
based and will be responsible for coordination of and technical and logistical support for the TA 
study and research work. The analyst will have relevant educational qualifications and work 
experience (including in conducting economic research, data collection, and statistical analyses), 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
excellent  written  and  verbal  communication  skills  in  English,  and  the  ability  to  meet  tight 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
deadlines. The analyst will work fulltime over the 2-year period and in cooperation with the 
designated OREI staff in carrying out the following tasks:

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(i)  provide technical and logistical support to the financial inclusion consultants, 
financial  consumer  protection  and  financial  literacy  specialist,  and  financial 
inclusion sector analyst in implementation of the TA; 
(ii)  proceed  with  data  collection  and  economic  research  as  requested  by  the 
financial  inclusion  consultants,  financial  consumer  protection  and  financial 
literacy specialist, and financial inclusion sector analyst through the designated 
OREI staff; 
(iii)  assist with arrangements related to the workshops for dissemination of selected 
studies  on  financial  inclusion  (output  2  of  the  TA)  and  organization  of  the 
workshop  with  DMCs  for  consultation  and  knowledge  sharing  on  financial 
consumer protection and financial literacy (output 3 of the TA); 
(iv)  assist with the publication and dissemination of various reports to be delivered 
under the TA; and 
(v)  provide other support in connection with TA implementation as requested by the 
designated OREI staff. 
 
6.     Web developer (national, 4 person-months intermittent). The web developer, who will 
be headquarters-based, will have as their major responsibility assisting in the development of a 
webpage on the financial inclusion knowledge platform under the ADB website and ADB portal, 
including development of the database structure. Specific tasks include: 
(i)  develop  a  knowledge  platform  that  will  provide  a  comprehensive  and  user-
friendly  source  of  information  on  ADB’s  experience  and  lessons  related  to 
financial inclusion; 
(ii)  conceptualize,  pilot,  and  implement  site  navigation  and  layout  improvements 
based on user feedback and conventional web usability principles and practices; 
(iii)  coordinate with relevant ADB staff in the Economics and Research Department, 
Office of Information Systems and Technology, and OREI to ensure that the 
platform is linked to their collaborative work on data integration and knowledge 
platforms; 
(iv)  coordinate with relevant ADB staff in the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department and the Office of Administrative Services to ensure the consistency 
and  alignment  of  the  knowledge  platform  under  this  TA  with  the  ADB-wide 
framework to extract and share embedded knowledge from ADB operations; 
(v)  create automated and/or improve existing systems to improve the speed and 
accuracy of ―back-end‖ processes such as data loading, cleaning, and extracting; 
(vi)  create and continually update functional and technical documentation pertaining 
to the site and data architecture and processes; 
(vii)  assist in maintaining the task management system and content management 
system databases;  
(viii)  diagnose and repair errors encountered in the website and back-end processes; 
(ix)  perform other tasks related to the website as assigned by the OREI staff. 
 
7.     National  financial  consumer  protection  and  financial  literacy  experts  (national, 
15 assignments, up to 1 person-month for each assignment, intermittent). One national expert in 
each of the DMCs participating in output 3 will be hired. They will support the international 
financial consumer protection and financial literacy specialist in delivering output 3 of the TA. 
Each national expert will have a bachelor’s degree in law or related fields, and at least 5 years’ 
experience on financial consumer protection or financial literacy in their country of assignment. 
The national experts will have good written and verbal communication skills in English, and be 
proficient in the local language. The tasks and responsibilities of the national experts include:

Appendix 3  13 
 
(i)  analyze the policy and legal framework, as well as the organization, features, and 
prevailing practices on financial consumer protection and financial literacy in the 
country of assignment; 
(ii)  collect information and prepare case descriptions of success stories and lessons 
on  financial  consumer  protection  and  financial  literacy  in  the  country  of 
assignment; 
(iii)  prepare a country report that combines (i) and (ii) above; 
(iv)  assist with coordination of and arrangements for the workshop with DMCs on 
financial consumer protection and financial literacy; and 
(v)  provide other support in connection with TA implementation as requested by the 
financial consumer protection and financial literacy specialist or designated OREI 
staff. 
 
B.   Reporting Arrangement 
 
8.  All consultants will report directly to ADB staff in charge of TA implementation. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.
